steps.title: Measure from your belt-line to the floor, double it, and add 20 cm (7.9 in).
steps.content: Measure from your belt-line to the floor, double it, and add 20 cm (7.9 in). If you prefer to wear your pants higher in the back and lower in the front, then start measuring from the highest point where you will wear the pants. This measurement will help you to determine how many yards of fabric to purchase. You will also need this measurement when it is time to cut the fabric for the pant length, so be sure to write it down. [1] X Research source For example, if your measurement is 75 cm (30 in), then double it for a total of 150 cm (59 in). Then, add 20 cm (7.9 in) for a final total of 170 cm (67 in). This is equal to about 1.85 yd (1.69 m), so you would need to round up and plan to purchase 2 yd (1.8 m) of fabric.

steps.title: Purchase your required amount of a fabric that is loose and gauzy.
steps.content: Purchase your required amount of a fabric that is loose and gauzy. Harem pants should feel loose and move well when you walk and dance in them. Opt for a fabric that is lightweight and flexible. [2] X Expert Source Mia Danilowicz Master Tailor Expert Interview. 8 January 2021. Gauzy cotton, silk, satin, chiffon, georgette, and jersey are all great options. [3] X Research source You can choose any color of fabric you like. Go with a solid color, a print, or a fabric that has been embellished, such as with sequins.

steps.title: Choose wide elastic for the waist and narrow elastic for the ankles.
steps.content: Choose wide elastic for the waist and narrow elastic for the ankles. The waist elastic should be about 2 to 2.5 cm (0.79 to 0.98 in) wide and the ankle elastic should be about 5 mm (0.20 in) wide. Purchase enough of the wide elastic to fit around your waist with a 2 cm (0.79 in) allowance and enough of the narrow elastic to fit around each of your ankles plus an extra 4 cm (1.6 in). [4] X Research source For example, if your waist is 60 cm (24 in), then opt for a piece of elastic that is 62 cm (24 in). If the circumference of each of your ankles is 17 cm (6.7 in), then double that for a total of 34 cm (13 in) and add 4 cm (1.6 in) for a total of 38 cm (15 in).

steps.title: Get a pair of shorts that fit you loosely.
steps.content: Get a pair of shorts that fit you loosely. The shorts will provide a guideline for creating the crotch and inseam of your harem pants. Make sure that the shorts are loose on you and that you can fit a hand in between your leg and the shorts while you are wearing them. If you donâ€™t have a pair of shorts, then pants will also work as long as they are loose. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Lay your fabric out on a flat, clean surface and fold it in half.
steps.content: Lay your fabric out on a flat, clean surface and fold it in half. Fold the fabric so that the shortest edges are lined up and the wrong (back or inside) of the fabric is facing out. Smooth out the fabric to ensure that there are no lumps or bumps. [6] X Research source If your fabric is wrinkled or has creases in it, then you may want to iron it first to ensure that it will lay flat. This is optional, but it will make cutting and sewing the fabric much easier.

steps.title: Turn your shorts inside out and fold them in half.
steps.content: Turn your shorts inside out and fold them in half. The inseam of the shorts needs to be exposed since it will be your guide for marking the fabric. Invert the shorts and fold them so that the legs are lined up. [7] X Research source You may also tuck 1 leg into the other leg if needed to make the inseam easier to see.

steps.title: Position the shorts waistband 4 cm (1.6 in) from the fold.
steps.content: Position the shorts waistband 4 cm (1.6 in) from the fold. Measure to ensure that the waistband is the correct distance from the fold. Then, position the crotch of the shorts about 1 cm (0.39 in) from the raw edge of your fabric. Adjust the shorts as needed to get the positioning right and ensure that the waistband is parallel to the fold. [8] X Research source Leaving space will provide fabric for the waistband casing and pantleg inseam.

steps.title: Trace the inseam 1 cm (0.39 in) from the curve.
steps.content: Trace the inseam 1 cm (0.39 in) from the curve. Use a fabric marker or chalk to create this line. Make sure that the line goes all the way from the edge of the fabric next to the crotch up to the top of the fold above the waistband. [9] X Research source The 1 cm (0.39 in) will provide the seam allowance when you sew the crotch.

steps.title: Measure from the fold to the bottom of the curve, then mark the edge.
steps.content: Measure from the fold to the bottom of the curve, then mark the edge. It is important to make both sides of the pantleg match up perfectly or your pants may look sloppy. Use this measurement to mark the fabric on the opposite side. [10] X Research source This mark will serve as a guideline for where to position the crotch of the shorts when you repeat the markings.

steps.title: Place the shorts 1 cm (0.39 in) from the mark and trace the curve.
steps.content: Place the shorts 1 cm (0.39 in) from the mark and trace the curve. Repeat the same process on the opposite side of the fabric to create an identical curve. Use the mark you made to help you position the shorts. Then, trace along the curve the same way that you did for the other side. [11] X Research source Keep in mind that the second curve will be going in the opposite direction of the first curve, but the 2 curves will match up perfectly when you fold the edges of the fabric together.

steps.title: Measure from the fold to find your desired pant length plus 6 cm (2.4 in).
steps.content: Measure from the fold to find your desired pant length plus 6 cm (2.4 in). Use the waist to floor pant length measurement that you found earlier. Then, add 6 cm (2.4 in) to it for seam allowance. Measure from the fold and mark the fabric with the measurement in a few places. Use the marks to draw a line across the fabric with a fabric marker or a piece of chalk. [12] X Research source For example, if your pant length is 75 cm (30 in), then add 6 cm (2.4 in) for a total of 81 cm (32 in). Mark the fabric 81 cm (32 in) from the fold.

steps.title: Cut along the line and down through the fold.
steps.content: Cut along the line and down through the fold. Use a sharp pair of fabric scissors to cut across the line you have drawn across the fabric. Then, cut straight across the fold to divide the fabric in half. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Separate the layers and fold each 1 in half lengthwise.
steps.content: Separate the layers and fold each 1 in half lengthwise. Match up the 2 sides of the fabric piece so that the curved edges are even and all of the straight edges are aligned. Make sure that the fabric is folded so that the wrong (inner or back) side of the fabric is facing out. [14] X Research source Repeat this for the second layer of fabric.

steps.title: Sew a straight stitch
steps.content: Sew a straight stitch along the inseam or straight edge. Set your sewing machine to the straight stitch setting, which is #1 on most sewing machines. Then, raise the presser foot and place the edge of your fabric under it. Lower the presser foot and apply gentle pressure to the pedal to start it. Hold the fabric taut in front of and behind the presser foot to help feed the fabric through as you sew. [15] X Research source Do not sew along the curved edge or along the top or bottom of the pantlegs. Only sew the straight edge extending down from the end of the curved edge.

steps.title: Repeat this for the other piece.
steps.content: Repeat this for the other piece. After you finish sewing 1 inseam, repeat the stitch to sew the second inseam. Sew the second seam exactly the same way as you sewed the first seam. [16] X Research source Remember, only sew along the straight edge!

steps.title: Turn 1 leg right side out and place it into the other leg.
steps.content: Turn 1 leg right side out and place it into the other leg. Keep the other leg facing wrong side out. Line up the inseam and the curved edges of the 2 legs as you do so. [17] X Research source This will make it easy to ensure that the seam is hidden as you sew the crotch.

steps.title: Insert pins into the fabric pieces along the curved edges.
steps.content: Insert pins into the fabric pieces along the curved edges. Place a pin every 4 to 6 cm (1.6 to 2.4 in) to secure the curved edges together. Insert each pin so that it is going perpendicular to the raw edge of the fabric. This will make it easier to remove the pins as you sew. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Sew a straight stitch along the pinned edges.
steps.content: Sew a straight stitch along the pinned edges. Set your sewing machine to the straight stitch setting and sew a straight stitch about 1 cm (0.39 in) from the raw edges of the curve. Sew from the beginning to the end of the curve. [20] X Research source Cut the excess thread when you reach the end of the curve.

steps.title: Fold over the top edge of the waistband by 1 cm (0.39 in).
steps.content: Fold over the top edge of the waistband by 1 cm (0.39 in). Separate the 2 legs and make sure that both legs are turned wrong side out. Then, fold over a small section of the top edge of the pants (where the waistband will be) by 1 cm (0.39 in). Hold the fold with your fingers. [21] X Research source This first fold is simply meant to create a hem and hide the raw edge of your fabric. [22] X Research source If desired, you may also iron the folds as you go. This is more work, but it will result in a crisper edge to your harem pants

steps.title: Make a 3 cm (1.2 in) fold and pin it.
steps.content: Make a 3 cm (1.2 in) fold and pin it. Repeat the fold in the same section, but this time make the fold 3 cm (1.2 in) wide. Hold this fold with your fingers and then insert a pin through both layers of folded fabric to hold them in place. [23] X Research source Iron this fold as well if you want to iron the folds as you go.

steps.title: Repeat the folds all the way around the waistband.
steps.content: Repeat the folds all the way around the waistband. Continue to fold and pin the fabric in this way going all the way around the waistband. Place a pin going perpendicular to the edge of the fabric every 4 to 6 cm (1.6 to 2.4 in). [24] X Research source

steps.title: Sew along the fold leaving a 5 cm (2.0 in) opening.
steps.content: Sew along the fold leaving a 5 cm (2.0 in) opening. Begin sewing near the center seam in the front or back of the pants. Sew all the way around the edges of the folded fabric until you are 5 cm (2.0 in) from where you started sewing. Stop sewing here to leave an opening that you can insert the elastic into. [26] X Research source Make sure to remove the pins as you sew. Do not sew over the pins or you may damage your sewing machine.

steps.title: Repeat this for the bottom of each of the pantlegs.
steps.content: Repeat this for the bottom of each of the pantlegs. Follow the same process for creating casings in the bottom of your pantlegs. However, make the second fold 1.5 cm (0.59 in) wide instead since the elastic is much narrower than the waistband elastic. [27] X Research source Remember to remove the pins as you sew!

steps.title: Measure the elastic around your waist and ankles and cut.
steps.content: Measure the elastic around your waist and ankles and cut. Use a pair of sharp fabric scissors to cut the elastic. Leave a 2 cm (0.79 in) allowance on each of the pieces for sewing the ends together. [28] X Research source If desired, you may take measurements of your waist and ankles and use these to determine how much of each type of elastic you need to cut. However, remember to add 2 cm (0.79 in) to each of the measurements.

steps.title: Attach safety pins to the elastic and insert 1 through the opening.
steps.content: Attach safety pins to the elastic and insert 1 through the opening. Secure 1 of the safety pins to the seam near the opening you left in the casing. Close the other safety pin at the end of the elastic. Insert this closed safety pin through the opening in the casing and use your fingers to work the safety pin through the casing until it comes out the other side. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the safety pins and sew the ends of the elastic band together.
steps.content: Remove the safety pins and sew the ends of the elastic band together. Once you have worked the end of the elastic all the way through the casing, hold the ends of the elastic so that they overlap and remove each of the safety pins. Sew a straight stitch across both pieces of elastic about 1 cm (0.39 in) from the ends of the elastic. [30] X Research source Do not sew over the pins! This may damage your sewing machine.

steps.title: Sew the opening closed with a straight stitch.
steps.content: Sew the opening closed with a straight stitch. Next, stretch the elastic slightly to bring the ends into the casing. Then, sew a straight stitch along the open edge of the casing to close it. [31] X Research source Make sure to refold the fabric in the open area if it has come undone.

steps.title: Repeat this for each of the pantlegs.
steps.content: Repeat this for each of the pantlegs. Once you have finished sewing the waistband, repeat the process to add the elastic to the casing for each of the pantlegs. Then, cut your excess threads. [32] X Research source Your harem pants are complete! Try them on and see how they look.
